My colleagues on the other side of the aisle need to know why protecting Roe is so important to you, your children and your community. 

Please QT this thread with your own stories. Speak up and say: codify Roe now.

I‚Äôm with you. (14/14)

Moms, I know we‚Äôre tired. But this Mother‚Äôs Day, I urge you to turn your frustration into action, make your voices heard and tell Congress that if they really want to honor moms today, they should start not by buying flowers or cards‚Äîbut by protecting our basic human rights.

But no, this is not about saving lives. It‚Äôs about controlling women.

It‚Äôs about taking away a freedom that more than half of our population has had access to for half a century.

And I refuse to let my daughters grow up in a world with fewer rights than I had.

They would be putting all of their efforts to addressing the growing maternal mortality crisis that has taken an alarming number of Black mothers‚Äô lives.

They would be pushing for desperately needed policies that support parents like affordable childcare and paid parental leave.

Let‚Äôs also make something clear: what‚Äôs happening is not about protecting life. If the anti-choice movement truly wanted to protect life, they‚Äôd advocate for policies like affordable, accessible postpartum healthcare and the expansion of Medicaid‚Äîthings that really do save lives.

So, you see, attempts to limit women‚Äôs reproductive choice, which can include limiting medical advancements like IVF, truly feel like a personal attack for me.

Because I‚Äôve lived what it means when choice and access to necessary, basic healthcare is not an option given to you.

Every day, I am grateful¬†beyond words for the miracle of IVF.

Because of IVF, I get to experience all the joys of motherhood.

Because of IVF, my husband and I are ‚Äúmommy and daddy.‚Äù

Because of IVF, we are a family.

Boy, did her badgering pay off!¬†

After many, many rounds of IVF‚Äîand some heartbreaking moments along the way, including a miscarriage‚ÄîI was able to bring both my girls into this world.

Thankfully, years later, a friend encouraged me‚Äîreally badgered me until I couldn‚Äôt refuse‚Äîto talk to her fertility doctor.

I didn‚Äôt want to go through the same disappointment of being told it wasn‚Äôt going to happen for me, but I finally made an appointment.
These folks weren‚Äôt honest about all of the options available to me due to religious objections and, because of it, my journey to bring my two beautiful girls into the world almost didn‚Äôt happen.

Unfortunately, a doctor at a private hospital basically confirmed my fear: I was past my prime baby-making years. 

They told me to just "go home and enjoy my husband.‚Äù

For a long time, I didn‚Äôt know if being a mom was in the cards for me.

What I knew was that I wanted to serve my country, so I joined the Army.

And after my helicopter was shot down, I wasn‚Äôt sure if I could revisit the idea of motherhood.

So right now‚Äîbefore every Senator votes to either protect or take away our right to choose next week‚Äîit‚Äôs so important that we speak out, share our stories and what this truly means for us and our families.

Here is my story. A story that would not be possible without Roe.

This Mother‚Äôs Day, I know what many of us moms are feeling: we're exhausted, struggling to hold it all together for our families and now our right to choose hangs in the balance. Mom to mom, I see you.

How dare anyone think that they know what's best for us? They don't. (1/14)
